suggested_resources.topic: Introduction to Longevity Science & Geroscience Hypothesis

book.title: Ending Aging: The Rejuvenation Breakthroughs That Could Reverse Human Aging in Our Lifetime
book.author: Aubrey de Grey and Michael Rae
book.reason: A provocative, well-known introduction to the idea that aging can be treated by targeting fundamental mechanisms; useful for students to understand the scope and controversies of geroscience.

podcast.title: Huberman Lab Podcast #55 — Aging: Science, Interventions, and What You Can Do
podcast.reason: Accessible expert interview that frames aging as a modifiable process and summarizes practical and research directions for a general audience; good for students seeking a broad overview.

article.title: Geroscience: Linking Aging to Chronic Disease
article.reason: A clear review article (open access) that explains the geroscience hypothesis and how targeting aging biology may affect multiple age-related diseases — appropriate as a foundational scientific reference.

suggested_resources.topic: Healthspan vs. Lifespan & Compression of Morbidity

book.title: Successful Aging
book.author: John W. Rowe and Robert L. Kahn
book.reason: A classic, well-cited book that defines concepts of successful aging and provides empirical and conceptual grounding for prioritizing healthspan over merely extending lifespan.

podcast.title: The Ezra Klein Show — Dan Buettner on the Blue Zones and what helps people live longer
podcast.reason: An accessible discussion of Blue Zones research and the lifestyle factors associated with longer, healthier lives—useful for linking epidemiology to practical behaviors.

article.title: Compression of morbidity revisited: a review of the evidence
article.reason: A scholarly review that evaluates evidence for the compression of morbidity concept and its implications for public health and individual behavior.

book.title: The Telomere Effect: A Revolutionary Approach to Living Younger, Healthier, Longer
book.author: Elizabeth Blackburn and Elissa Epel
book.reason: Written by the Nobel laureate who discovered telomeres and a leading psychologist; connects molecular mechanisms (telomeres) to lifestyle interventions in clear, student-friendly language.

podcast.title: The Peter Attia Drive — #130: Cellular Senescence and Senolytics (guest: Judith Campisi)
podcast.reason: Features a prominent researcher on senescence; provides nuanced discussion of biology, evidence, and the translational potential of senolytics appropriate for engaged undergraduates.

article.title: The Hallmarks of Aging: An Expanding Universe (Cell, 2023 update)
article.reason: The updated, authoritative review of the hallmarks framework that introduces the current set of hallmarks and discusses connections like telomere attrition and senescence — essential reading for the course.

suggested_resources.topic: Theories of Aging (programmed vs. damage-based; Hayflick limit, free radicals)

book.title: Why We Age — And Why We Don't Have To: The Groundbreaking Science of Radical Life Extension
book.author: David A. Sinclair
book.reason: Provides one scientist's perspective on mechanisms of aging and interventions; useful for stimulating discussion about programmed vs. damage-based theories (note: interpret with critical perspective).

podcast.title: Science Vs — 'Aging' episode
podcast.reason: A balanced, journalistically driven episode that compares competing theories and separates evidence from hype—good for students learning to evaluate claims.

article.title: The Hayflick Limit and Cellular Senescence
article.reason: A clear, authoritative explainer suitable for students that summarizes the Hayflick discovery and its relevance to aging biology.

suggested_resources.topic: Evaluating Evidence & Research Methods in Longevity

book.title: How to Read a Paper: The Basics of Evidence-Based Medicine and Healthcare
book.author: Trisha Greenhalgh
book.reason: An accessible primer on evaluating study design, causation vs. association, and critical appraisal—very practical for students learning to assess longevity claims.

podcast.title: Econtalk — 'Science and Pseudoscience in the Age of Longevity' (guest: Naomi Oreskes)
podcast.reason: A discussion that helps students recognize scientific standards versus hype and reinforces critical thinking about extraordinary claims in emerging fields.

article.title: GRADE: An emerging consensus on rating quality of evidence and strength of recommendations
article.reason: Introduces the GRADE framework referenced in the script; useful for students to understand how guideline bodies assess evidence quality and recommendation strength.

suggested_resources.topic: Four Pillars of Healthspan: Exercise, Nutrition, Sleep, Emotional Health

book.title: Outlive: The Science & Art of Longevity
book.author: Peter Attia
book.reason: A contemporary, practical synthesis by a translational clinician-scientist that covers exercise, nutrition, sleep, and mental health with attention to evidence and implementation for adults.

podcast.title: The Drive — 'Zone 2 Training, Strength, and Longevity' (episode with exercise physiologist)
podcast.reason: Practical audio that explains Zone 2, strength training, and mobility in the context of longevity, matching the course emphasis on actionable interventions.

article.title: Blue Zones: Lessons for Living Longer From the People Who've Lived the Longest
article.reason: An accessible, reputable summary of the Blue Zones findings that links lifestyle patterns to longevity and complements scientific literature with population-level observations.

suggested_resources.topic: Sleep and Emotional Health (biological impacts of sleep, stress, telomeres)

book.title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
book.author: Matthew Walker
book.reason: A readable synthesis of sleep science that explains mechanisms (glymphatic clearance, hormones) and public-health implications—helpful and persuasive for students.

podcast.title: The Happiness Lab — 'The Power of Connection' (episode about social ties and health)
podcast.reason: Shows how social connection and emotional health affect well-being and longevity, translating research into relatable stories and takeaways for students.

article.title: Stress and Telomere Biology: A Review
article.reason: A scholarly review linking psychological stress to telomere shortening and biological aging—directly relevant to the script's discussion of emotional health and cellular aging.

suggested_resources.topic: Diagnostics & Emerging Therapeutics (epigenetic clocks, senolytics, rapamycin, TRIIM, reprogramming)

book.title: Lifespan: Why We Age—and Why We Don't Have To
book.author: David A. Sinclair
book.reason: Provides a readable account of epigenetic clocks, reprogramming concepts, and many of the drug candidates (rapamycin, metformin) sparking research and debate—good for sparking classroom discussion.

podcast.title: The Long Now Foundation / Tim Ferriss — Interview with Steve Horvath on epigenetic clocks
podcast.reason: An interview that introduces epigenetic clocks in accessible terms from a leading researcher, useful to understand how biological age is measured and interpreted.

article.title: TRIIM Trial: Reversal of epigenetic age and immunosenescent trends in humans
article.reason: Primary report of the TRIIM study (open access) that students can read to evaluate claims about epigenetic age reversal and practice critical appraisal of trial limitations.

suggested_resources.topic: Ethics, Equity, and Social Implications of Longevity Interventions

book.title: The End of Old Age: Living a Longer, More Purposeful Life
book.author: Marc E. Agronin
book.reason: Offers thoughtful consideration of the psychological, social, and ethical dimensions of extended life and healthy aging—helps students reflect beyond biological mechanisms.

podcast.title: Philosophize This! — 'Bioethics and the Future of Human Enhancement'
podcast.reason: Accessible philosophical exploration of ethical issues raised by life-extension technologies; useful for class debates and assignments about societal impacts.

article.title: Equity and access to longevity medicine: Policy and ethical issues
article.reason: A reputable commentary discussing ethical and policy challenges of emerging longevity therapies; useful for grounding classroom discussion in current scholarly debate.
